fields.Primary Story Content:
Gentle Relentlessness 

Una inquietud suave 

From First Generation to Vice President 

De primera generación a vicepresidenta 

Mary Ontiveros 

 

"She never gave up trying to improve the place and the people" - Tony Frank 

"Ella nunca dejó de intentar mejorar el lugar y la gente" - Tony Frank 

Mary Ontiveros came to CSU as a first-generation college student in 1969. A humble woman, she likely never imagined serving in so many leadership roles nor culminating her career as CSU Vice President for Diversity. “Nobody had seen the scope of change at CSU that she had,” Frank said. 

Mary Ontiveros llegó a CSU como estudiante universitaria de primera generación en 1969. Una mujer humilde, probablemente nunca imaginó desempeñar tantos roles de liderazgo ni culminar su carrera como vicepresidenta de diversidad de CSU. “Nadie había visto el alcance del cambio en CSU que ella tenía”, dijo Frank. 

 

Persistence led to diverse experiences which led to immense impacts 

La persistencia la llevó a diversas experiencias que llevaron a inmensos impactos. 

Born and raised one of six children, she credited her parents for her drive and work ethic. They insisted she go to college but lacked the funds to cover costs. "You do what you have to do, right? I would go all around campus asking for different jobs, so I came to know the university quite a bit.” These experiences and her relentless pursuit of inclusivity and access to higher education for all left a legacy. 

Nacida y criada como una de seis hijos, le dio crédito a sus padres por su empuje y ética de trabajo. Insistieron en que fuera a la universidad, pero carecían de los fondos para cubrir los costos. “Haces lo que tienes que hacer, ¿verdad? Iba por todo el campus pidiendo diferentes trabajos, así que llegué a conocer bastante la universidad”. Estas experiencias y su incansable búsqueda de la inclusión y el acceso a la educación superior para todos dejaron un legado. 

 

Helping CSU become a more just and equitable community 

Ayudar a CSU a convertirse en una comunidad más justa y equitativa 

 

Mary went on to earn her BS in Psychology. Following her graduation, Ontiveros started a long career at CSU, starting out as a research associate in 1974 and working her way up to from an administrative assistant in the Chicano Studies Office to acting director of Chicano Student Services and then to associate director of admissions, associate vice president for enrollment and access, and ultimately vice president of diversity. 

Mary obtuvo su BS en Psicología. Después de su graduación, Ontiveros empezó una larga carrera en CSU, comenzando como investigadora asociada en 1974 y ascendiendo desde asistente administrativa en la Oficina de Estudios Chicanos hasta directora provisional de Chicano Student Services y luego directora asociada de admisiones, vicepresidenta asociada de inscripción y acceso y, en última instancia, vicepresidenta de diversidad. 

Every step of the way, she used her knowledge gained over half a century’s worth at CSU to provide perspective on how the university got to where it was, where it is headed and what that means for students of all races, ethnicities, and socio-economic statuses. From having to add a letter to an Asian student's two-letter first name to be able to be entered into enrollment systems to being told "told the university is not ready to have two Latinx women in a leadership position in the same office" the legacy she left will be a changed University that must continue its journey towards become more diverse, just, equitable, and inclusive. 

En cada paso del camino, utilizó su conocimiento adquirido durante medio siglo en CSU para brindar una perspectiva sobre cómo la universidad llegó a donde estaba, hacia dónde se dirigía y qué significa eso para los estudiantes de todas las razas, etnias y estados socioeconómicos. Desde tener que agregar una letra al nombre de dos letras de un estudiante asiático para poder ingresar en los sistemas de inscripción hasta que le dijeran que "la universidad no está lista para tener dos mujeres latinx en una posición de liderazgo en la misma oficina" el legado que dejó será una universidad cambiada que debe continuar su camino hacia ser más diversa, justa, equitativa e incluyente. 

 

“She made CSU a better place through her presence and that quiet, yet relentless commitment. … I’m proud to have worked alongside her, proud to call her my friend, and am a better human being for knowing her.” - Tony Frank 

“Ella hizo de CSU un mejor lugar a través de su presencia y ese compromiso silencioso pero implacable. … Estoy orgulloso de haber trabajado junto a ella, orgulloso de llamarla mi amiga y soy un mejor ser humano por conocerla”. -Tony Frank

fields.Research Focus: Kenya: Leads food initiative at Rockefeller in Nairobi
fields.Primary Story Content:
Transforming Food Systems | Transformar los sistemas alimentarios 

Transforming the fresh produce markets in Africa | Transformación de los mercados de productos frescos en África 

 

Educational Pathway:   

Bachelor of Science, Agribusiness Management, Egerton University 

Master of Science, Agricultural and Resource Economics, Colorado State University 

Educación: 

Licenciatura en Ciencias, Gestión de Agronegocios, Universidad de Egerton 

Maestría en Ciencias, Economía Agrícola y de Recursos, Universidad Estatal de Colorado 

 

Smart Food Markets  

Betty Kibaara is a Director in the Food Initiative at The Rockefeller Foundation, Africa Region Office. At the Foundation, Betty leads investments in transforming food systems, specifically investments in innovations on smart food markets for the future, increasing access to nutritious foods through instructional procurement. She is also advancing insect-based feed for improved nutrition.  

Mercados de alimentos inteligentes 

Betty Kibaara es Directora de la Iniciativa Alimentaria en la Oficina de la Región de África de la Fundación Rockefeller. En la Fundación, Betty lidera inversiones en la transformación de los sistemas alimentarios, específicamente inversiones en innovaciones en mercados de alimentos inteligentes para el futuro, aumentando el acceso a alimentos nutritivos a través de la adquisición instructiva. También está promoviendo alimentos a base de insectos para mejorar la nutrición. 

Improving Farmer Livelihood  

Kibaara led the implementation of the YieldWise Initiative to reduce food loss in Corn in Tanzania, Mangoes in Kenya, and Cassava and Tomato value chains to improve livelihoods for the smallholder farmers in Africa.  

Mejorar el sustento de los agricultores 

Kibaara lideró la implementación de la iniciativa YieldWise para reducir la pérdida de maíz en Tanzania, mangos en Kenia y  cadenas de valor de yuca y tomate para mejorar la vida de los pequeños agricultores en África. 

Transforming Produce Markets in Africa  

Kibaara believes that there is no food system transformation without transforming the fresh produce markets in Africa. She serves as the regional champion for the Rockefeller Foundation’s initiatives in strengthening food security, agribusiness, and resilience to the devastating effects of climate change to enable real, sustainable, and equitable economic growth.  

Transformar los mercados de productos agrícolas en África 

Kibaara cree que no hay transformación del sistema alimentario sin transformar los mercados de productos frescos en África. Se desempeña como defensora regional de las iniciativas de la Fundación Rockefeller para fortalecer la seguridad alimentaria, los agronegocios y la resiliencia a los efectos devastadores del cambio climático para permitir un crecimiento económico real, sostenible y equitativo. 

Educational Background  

Before joining the Rockefeller Foundation in 2009, Kibaara worked as a Research Fellow at the Tegemeo Institute of Agricultural Policy and Development, Egerton University. She holds a Master of Science degree in Agricultural and Resource Economics from Colorado State University and a Bachelor of Science in Agribusiness Management from Egerton University in Kenya. 

Formación educativa 

Antes de unirse a la Fundación Rockefeller en 2009, Kibaara trabajó como investigadora en el Instituto Tegemeo de Política y Desarrollo Agrícola de la Universidad de Egerton. Tiene una Maestría en Ciencias en Economía Agrícola y de Recursos de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado y una Licenciatura en Ciencias en Gestión de Agronegocios de la Universidad de Egerton en Kenia.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Say hi to strangers 

The first thing you notice about Colorado State University custodian Robert Serunjogi is that he’s very outgoing and friendly 

Saludar a los desconocidos 

Lo primero que se nota sobre el conserje de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, Robert Serunjogi, es que es muy extrovertido y amigable. 

 

A friendship is born 

A conversation Robert Serunjogi struck up with a complete stranger more than four years ago not only blossomed into a friendship, but a fundraising campaign that generated almost $70,000 to build schools for orphans in his home country of Uganda. 

“I say ‘Hi’ to a lot of strangers, and this time it paid off” he says. “I got that from my grandmother. She’d say that if you don’t say ‘How are you?’ how are you going to make friends?” 

Laura Schreck was a CSU graduate student at the time Robert said hello. She started a GoFundMe campaign after hearing from him about the need to raise money to build schools in his home village in Uganda. 

Nace una amistad 

Una conversación que Robert Serunjogi entabló con un desconocido hace más de cuatro años no solo se convirtió en una amistad, sino en una campaña de recaudación de fondos que generó casi $70,000 para construir escuelas para huérfanos en su país de origen, Uganda. 

"Digo 'Hola' a muchos extraños, y esta vez valió la pena", dice. “Eso lo heredé de mi abuela. Ella decía que si no dices '¿Cómo estás?' ¿Cómo vas a hacer amigos?” 

Laura Schreck era una estudiante de posgrado de CSU en el momento en que Robert la saludó. Ella comenzó una campaña de GoFundMe después de escuchar de él sobre la necesidad de recaudar dinero para construir escuelas en su pueblo natal en Uganda. 

 

Role of Education 

Ultimately, Serunjogi — who juggles a job at McDonald’s with his custodial work at the University — wants to return to Uganda and work as a teacher. “For me, education is very important, because if everyone had access to education, the world would be safer,” he says. “The community can benefit from you if you get a good education.” 

And Serunjogi, who earned his bachelor’s degree in political science from CSU, adds that education opens doors as well - just as it has for Laura who graduated with an MS in Health and Exercise Science in May 2019. 

“Having an education gives you the power to be independent,” he says. “I want that for the children of my village.” 

El papel de la educación 

En última instancia, Serunjogi, que tiene que balancear un trabajo en McDonald's con su trabajo de custodia en la Universidad, quiere regresar a Uganda y trabajar como maestro. “Para mí la educación es muy importante, porque si todos tuvieran acceso a la educación, el mundo sería más seguro”, dice. “La comunidad puede beneficiarse de ti si obtienes una buena educación”. 

Y Serunjogi, quien obtuvo su licenciatura en ciencias políticas de CSU, agrega que la educación también abre puertas, tal como lo hizo para Laura, quien se graduó con una maestría en ciencias de la salud y el ejercicio en mayo de 2019. 

“Tener una educación te da el poder de ser independiente”, dice. “Quiero eso para los niños de mi pueblo”. 

 

Making an Impact 

The buildings serve as schools, health clinics and dorms for about 180 children between the ages of 4 and 14. 

“Now we have buildings with roofs,” Serunjogi says. “When it rains, we don’t have to interrupt class to get under a tree." 

Schreck had the opportunity to visit and brought with her CSU's Little Shop of Physics crew. Jones, director of the Little Shop of Physics and an instructor in the Department of Physics, and Ferguson, an LSOP teacher in residence, brought 750 pounds of science education materials in more than 20 suitcases that they left at Serunjogi’s village after introducing their curriculum to students and teachers alike. 

“We’re putting resources into a well-run organization,” Jones said. 

Schreck says Serunjogi’s friends and relatives in the very family-oriented, community-centric village were worried about whether he had found a good community in the United States. “People would say, ‘Thank you for taking care of Robert,’” Schreck says. “They were glad to meet his community in the U.S., and we would tell them, ‘Thank you for letting us take care of him and letting us have Robert in our lives.’” 

Tener un impacto 

Los edificios sirven como escuelas, clínicas de salud y dormitorios para unos 180 niños de entre 4 y 14 años. 

“Ahora tenemos edificios con techos”, dice Serunjogi. “Cuando llueve, no tenemos que interrumpir la clase para meternos debajo de un árbol”. 

Schreck tuvo la oportunidad de visitar y trajo consigo el equipo Little Shop of Physics de CSU. Jones, director del equipo Little Shop of Physics e instructor en el Departamento de Física, y Ferguson, maestro residente de LSOP, trajeron 750 libras de materiales de educación científica en más de 20 maletas que dejaron en el pueblo de Serunjogi después de presentar su plan de estudios a estudiantes y profesores. 

“Estamos poniendo recursos en una organización bien administrada”, dijo Jones. 

Schreck dice que los amigos y parientes de Serunjogi en el pueblo centrado en la comunidad y orientado a la familia estaban preocupados por si había encontrado una buena comunidad en los Estados Unidos. "La gente decía: 'Gracias por cuidar de Robert'", dice Schreck. “Estaban contentos de conocer a su comunidad en los EE. UU., y les decíamos: ‘Gracias por permitirnos cuidarlo y permitirnos tener a Robert en nuestras vidas'”. 

 

“Having an education gives you the power to be independent” - Robert Serunjogi 

“Tener una educación te da el poder de ser independiente” - Robert Serunjogi

fields.Primary Story Content: In Honduras, a previously hidden ancient city came to light when archaeologist and CSU professor Chris Fisher used LiDAR technology to look under the dense tree canopy and undergrowth of the jungle. Fisher’s groundbreaking, or really ground-viewing, use of LiDAR has changed the face of modern archaeology, speeding discovery by radically shortening the time it takes to “uncover” previously undiscovered sites. Ultimately, Fisher’s research expeditions in the jungles of Honduras and Mexico aim to help us better understand the causes and consequences of urbanism and environmental change.

Dr. Ramesh Akkina is a professor of Microbiology, Immunology, and Pathology at Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA. 

A PhD from the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, he did his post-doctoral work and was a visiting professor at the UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles. 

He is a leading researcher in the HIV field and made many ground breaking discoveries in viral infectious diseases. His early contributions were in Influenza virology and stem-cell based gene therapy strategies. His lab pioneered in work with humanized mice with a transplanted human immune system for HIV and Dengue virus research as well as for delivery of novel gene therapy molecules. 

Recent work developed new pre-exposure prophylaxis methods to prevent HIV transmission, successfully tested anti-HIV si-RNAs and aptamers and showed that immune exhaustion during HIV infection can be partly reversed by PD-1 blockade. 

Ongoing work is centered on HIV latency, prevention, novel therapeutics and viral evolution. His research is supported by multiple NIH grants. He is a member of many editorial and international grant review boards. He is currently the Center Director for Global Virus Network at Colorado State University and Chair of the NIH AIDS ADDT grant review study section.

There are currently more than 40 million victims of slavery around the world, with most of them being women and girls. This illegal industry generates approximately $150 billion every year. Dr. Lumina Albert, associate professor of management in the College of Business at CSU, applies her background in management and marketing to the fight against human trafficking in the U.S. and abroad. As a board member for Rescue:Freedom International and consultant for other organizations, Albert provides key input on issues ranging from strategic public relations to organizing social marketing campaigns.

fields.Research Focus: Dr. Mahmoud’s research program has three major thrusts. The first thrust pertains to spatial and temporal quantification of community resilience subjected to extreme natural hazards including wildfires, tornados, hurricanes, flooding, and earthquakes. The second thrust is focused on assessment and development of resilient and sustainable infrastructure systems subjected to natural and man-made hazards including single and multi-hazards such as blast, fire, earthquakes, and wind or the combination of such. The third major thrust pertains to assessment, evaluation, and repair of deteriorated infrastructure subjected to high and low-cycle fatigue. He has conducted various studies on fatigue evaluation and he has performed numerous in-service assessment of major structures across the U.S. that resulted in the development of proto-type retrofits that have successfully been implemented and adopted by various design specifications.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Committed to teaching students up-to-date, relevant professional skills, all CSU Global faculty are required to have recent industry experience and many remain active in their field. One of CSU Global’s prominent faculty members, Criminal Justice Program Director Dr. J. Michael Skiba, is a prime example as an international leading expert on financial and cyber crime. Trademarking the name “Dr. Fraud,” with over 25 years of experience in special investigations, Dr. Skiba has operated in over 96 countries and is regularly called upon by top agencies in the world to assist with fraud prevention, such as the United Nations, the FBI, and the CIA. Earlier this year, Dr. Skiba partnered with the Coalition Against Insurance Fraud and led a team of researchers to measure the annual cost of insurance fraud in the U.S.--which came out to $309 billion–a figure that has not been calculated since 1995. Dr. Skiba travels on a regular basis sharing his expertise and speaking at the world’s leading fraud conferences.

As a recent example, in August 2022, Dr. Skiba traveled to Thailand with the United Nations, where he worked with all of the military, police, and VIPs (political, etc.)]to train them on the threats from cybercrime and fraud. The below picture features Dr. Skiba in the middle surrounded by Thailand's most elite police unit--the Thailand Royal Police, and also members from the UN, Interpol and Europol.
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Zoomed in image of hands typing on a laptop

fields.Primary Story Content: Alumna Deirdre Jonker’s time as a CSU Global student can be quantified in “twos” — two continents and two degrees. Jonker is a dual citizen of the U.S. and the Netherlands, and she has graduated with her Bachelor’s in Criminal Justice and Master’s in Information Technology Management. With the skills she gained during her education, Jonker set out to develop an app. She looked into how people suffer from addictions and behavior related to the use (or misuse) of pharmaceuticals and wanted to provide an alternative that would help people mentally, physically, and financially. In 2020, she participated in the Google Developers Console and developed Comspeare, a free app that releases 40Hz GAVA waves to help users relax during stressful times and reduce anxiety with sound. The app published in the Google Play Store and the Apple App Store in 2021. Today, Jonker lives in Amsterdam, promoting Comspeare and reaching out to medical and health care institutions to see if the app could benefit their patients.

fields.Primary Story Content: CSU Global’s flexible course structure, dedicated military benefits team, military friendliness academic policy, and military-affiliated tuition discounts have earned it the rank of no. 6 in the nation for Best Online Programs for Veterans according to U.S. News & World Report. The university is not only home to many active-duty service members and veterans, but their family members as well. Alumna Kirsten Hackett, a military spouse, sought an online program while she was living in Japan, where her husband was deployed. “Being in another time zone on a different continent, I knew I wouldn’t be able to be in class at a set time,” Hackett said. The ability to pause coursework at CSU Global also appealed to her, as students may take a break for up to 12 months and still remain in good academic standing. That option can help accommodate the unpredictable life of a military spouse; for instance, in the event of a move. Kirsten earned her B.S. in Marketing and is currently putting the skills she learned in her degree program to use as Senior Social Media Strategist at Stealth Creative. Even though she needed to move to another country when her husband deployed, Kirsten did not have to put her own professional aspirations on hold. She was able to earn her degree while living oversees and land the career of her dreams upon returning to the U.S.
fields.Spatial Angle: Kirsten lived in Japan when she started her program at CSU Global, and she currently lives in St. Louis, MO, where she works as a senior social media strategist.

fields.Primary Story Content:
It's impossible to know if a seed is alive or dead without the testing done by seed labs.  That's pretty incredible for something that has so much significance and influence on the survival of humans and animals.  
For the farmers and gardeners who produce the food we rely on, or conservationists who are reclaiming land that has been damaged, seed analysts and seed labs they work in, are the glue that holds the seed industry and agriculture as whole, together.  The Seed Industry accounts for nearly 22 million jobs in the United States, this includes seed analysts and labs they work in like the Colorado Seed Lab.  The Colorado Seed Lab has been operating at Colorado State University in Fort Collins for over 100 years.
Seed labs find out how vigorously a seed will grow by testing its germination.  How vigorously will the seed one plants germinate?  100% of them, 20% of them, or none?  Farmers, gardeners and conservationists need to know how many seeds will germinate before they plant them.  Seed analysts also look at what else may be in that bag.  Are there seeds from weeds or other crop plants in that bag of seeds to be planted?  Some of those extra or unwanted seeds, may produce noxious weeds or unwanted crops.  Seed analysts can identify what plant a seed will become without seeing the actual plant, a pretty rare skill for botanists!   Most plant identification is done by looking at the whole plant.  Seed labs give all this information to the people or companies selling seed.  All seed sellers and distributors have to put the information the lab gives them (germination and purity of the seed lot) on a label that is attached to the container of seed before its distributed.  That way the consumer can determine if they want to buy and plant that bag of seed or not.  
Seed has moved all around the world for centuries.  No matter where the seed was grown, the companies or people distributing and receiving that seed rely on testing done at a seed lab to know how healthy and vigorous that seed is.  The Colorado Seed Lab is proud to provide this vital information to both the seed industry and to consumers (those who plant seeds) locally and around the world.
Seeds grown in Colorado that produce grain, vegetables, fiber, and forage are exported all over the world.  Millet grain grown in Colorado is exported to countries like Indonesia, Australia, and New Zealand.  Beans grown in Colorado are exported to countries like Mexico.  Flower seeds produced in Colorado are exported to the European Union, Great Britan and countries like China.  Hemp seeds produced in Colorado are exported to countries like Uruguay, and other US states and territories including Puerto Rico.  Hard Red Winter Wheat is Colorado's top crop, grown on over 2 million acres in the state, all of which originates from seed.  75 to 80% of grain that is harvested from Colorado wheat fields is exported to other countries.  Mexico, Nigeria and Japan round out the top three.
fields.Spatial Angle: US and Colorado, however all seed labs follow similar international standards, and these labs exit all over the world. Seeds move all around the world.  Seed quality must be communicated to all receiving parties whether they be in other countries or the garden center or coop down the street.

fields.Third Grade Level Story:
Seeds are one of the most important ingredients for human survival.  Without seeds, the plants that provide our food, fuel, fiber, oxygen, and many other essential products would not exist.  
Good quality, strong seeds are needed for farmers and gardeners to grow the food we rely on, or for conservationists who are reclaiming land that has been damaged.  It's impossible to know if a seed is alive or dead without a Seed Lab and the Seed Analysts that work there.  They find out how strongly a seed will grow by testing its germination or the seed's ability to send out roots and form shoots. Seed germination can be somewhat mysterious because is usually occurs undergrounds where we can't see what's happening.
Farmers, gardeners and conservationists need to know how many seeds will germinate before they plant them.  Seed analysts also look at what else may be 'hiding' in the bag of seeds we plant.  Are there extra seeds from weeds or other crop plants in that bag of seeds to be planted?  Some of those extra or unwanted seeds, may produce noxious weeds or other crops that the farmer or land manager does not want.  Seed analysts have special skills, they can identify the plant that seed will become!   Seed labs give all this information to the people selling seed.  People selling seed have to put the information the lab gives them about germination and other weed or crops seeds on a label so farmers and gardeners can know what's in the bag.  That way the consumer can determine if they want to buy and plant that bag of seed or not.  
People move seed all over the world.  No matter where the seed was grown, the companies or people distributing and receiving that seed rely on testing done at a seed lab to know how healthy and strong that seed is.   Seed labs exist in every state of the U.S. and in every country around the world.  As well, the crops grown from seed in Colorado are exported to countries all over the world.
fields.Impactful Quote:
"Pretty much all agriculture starts with the seed.  Anything that ends up on your dinner plate, somehow seed is involved with that."  Randy Crowl, RST, Colorado Seed Lab Manger, CSU.

"I find our job really important because we are testing seed quality to feed the world."  Kaitlyn Fulmer, Biological Science Aide, USDA Gene Laboratory (National Laboratory for Genetic Preservation)

"Any seed sold in the world has to be tested" Richard Agnew, RST, Applewood Seed

"Without seeds, our food supply, clothing, buildings, beautiful scenery, soil stability, wildlife habitat, energy and other products vital to life would no longer be available."  Laura Pottorff, Director of Colorado Seed Programs, CSU

fields.Primary Story Content:
Stewardship and Science | La mayordomía y la ciencia 
Strengthening Research and Relationships in Puerto Rico  | Fortalecer la investigación y las relaciones en Puerto Rico 
 
Dr. Dominique David-Chavez is working to share and gather knowledge across boundaries and communities. 
In Puerto Rico, and with Indigenous groups around the world, Dr. David-Chavez invites and includes Indigenous people into data models and research. 
La Dra. Dominique David-Chavez está trabajando para compartir y recopilar conocimientos a través de fronteras y comunidades. 
En Puerto Rico, y con grupos indígenas de todo el mundo, la Dra. David-Chavez invita e incluye a los indígenas en los modelos de datos y la investigación. 
In Puerto Rico, Dr. David-Chavez is working with communities to support community-based climate research. 
This research is sponsored by the National Science Foundation and is led through the Haskell Indian Nations University in Lawrence, Kansas. In addition to Puerto Rico, this group is also doing research in Alaska, Louisiana, and Hawaii. 
En Puerto Rico, la Dra. David-Chavez está trabajando con las comunidades para apoyar la investigación climática basada en la comunidad. 
Esta investigación está patrocinada por la Fundación Nacional de Ciencias y está dirigida por la Universidad Haskell Indian Nations en Lawrence, Kansas. Además de Puerto Rico, este grupo también está investigando en Alaska, Luisiana y Hawái. 
"We need to address the exclusion of marginalized communities in the sciences and the deficit that we recognize from that exclusion."- Dr. Dominque David-Chavez 
Dr. David-Chavez works alongside volunteers and community scientists to collect data from the shorelines that will help inform efforts for vegetation restoration in area where water is wearing away at the coastline. 
"Necesitamos abordar la exclusión de las comunidades marginadas en las ciencias y el déficit que reconocemos de esa exclusión". - Dra. Dominque David-Chavez 
La Dra. David-Chavez trabaja junto con voluntarios y científicos de la comunidad para recopilar datos de las costas que ayudarán a informar los esfuerzos para la restauración de la vegetación en el área donde el agua está desgastando la costa. 
Dr. Dominque David-Chavez is assistant professor of Indigenous Natural Resource Stewardship in the Forest and Rangeland Stewardship Department. 
In this department, students learn how to be stewards of natural resources and to take care of the earth. 
La Dra. Dominique David-Chavez es profesora asistente de Administración de Recursos Naturales Indígenas en el Departamento de Administración de Bosques y Pastizales. 
En este departamento, los estudiantes aprenden a ser buenas custodias de los recursos naturales y a cuidar la tierra. 
Dr. David-Chavez also leads the Indigenous and Data Stewards Laboratory at Colorado State University. 
This laboratory incorporates Indigenous ways of knowing and community values with innovative scientific research and education. 
La Dra. David-Chavez también dirige el Laboratorio de Administradores Indígenas y de Datos en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado. 
Este laboratorio incorpora las formas indígenas de conocimiento y los valores comunitarios a la investigación científica y educación innovadoras.

fields.Primary Story Content:
International Social Work | El trabajo social internacional 
 
Marisa Gonzalez grew up in a small town and didn’t leave her home state of South Dakota until age 18. Still, she knew she wanted more. She didn’t simply want to see the world, she wanted to change the world and make it a better place. 
Marisa González creció en un pueblo pequeño y no abandonó su estado natal de Dakota del Sur hasta los 18 años. Aun así, sabía que quería más. Ella no solo quería ver el mundo, quería cambiar el mundo y hacerlo un lugar mejor. 
  
“I grew up in a low-income family, and my youth was spent in this tiny, tiny spot on the map,” she said. “Even though I was the first one in my family to go to college, I knew I wanted to travel and do international social work. College really opened my eyes to new opportunities, new ways to make an impact.” 
 “Crecí en una familia de bajos ingresos y pasé mi juventud en este diminuto lugar en el mapa”, dijo. “Aunque fui la primera de mi familia en ir a la universidad, sabía que quería viajar y hacer trabajo social internacional. La universidad realmente me abrió los ojos a nuevas oportunidades, nuevas formas de generar un impacto”. 
 
Gonzalez, now a professor of social work at CSU Pueblo, did study abroad in Western Europe, and based her master’s thesis on her time interning as a social worker in Nepal. Those experiences fueled her passion for helping underprivileged populations, both in the U.S. and abroad. 
González, ahora profesora de trabajo social en CSU Pueblo, estudió en el extranjero en Europa Occidental y basó su tesis de maestría en su tiempo de pasantía como trabajadora social en Nepal. Esas experiencias alimentaron su pasión por ayudar a las poblaciones desfavorecidas, tanto en los EE. UU. como en el extranjero. 
 
“I felt like I had the world at my fingertips,” she said. “And I wanted to be the person who can help others experience those same things.” 
When she first heard that CSU Pueblo students would have access to the Todos Santos Center in Baja California Sur Mexico, she immediately wanted to be involved. The Todos Santos  
Center, established in 2014, provides a variety of research and educational opportunities that would not otherwise be available to CSU students. 
 “Sentí que tenía el mundo al alcance de mi mano”, dijo. “Y quería ser la persona que pudiera ayudar a otros a experimentar esas mismas cosas”. 
Cuando escuchó por primera vez que los estudiantes de CSU Pueblo tendrían acceso al Centro Todos Santos en Baja California Sur, México, inmediatamente quiso participar. El Centro Todos Santos, establecido en 2014, brinda una variedad de oportunidades educativas y de investigación que de otro modo no estarían disponibles a los estudiantes de CSU. 
 
Gonzalez is eager to take CSU Pueblo students to Todos Santos and give them a taste of the same international education that shaped her. She has established a relationship with a university near Todos Santos and hopes social work programs at both universities benefit. 
 González está ansiosa por llevar a los estudiantes de CSU Pueblo a Todos Santos y darles una muestra de la misma educación internacional que la formó. Ella ha establecido una relación con una universidad cerca de Todos Santos y espera que los programas de trabajo social en ambas universidades se beneficien. 
 
“Our students will be learning about another culture through actually being there and experiencing it,” she said. “The people in Todos Santos were willing to give us their time, their energy, their information. A lot of our students are first-generation, bilingual and, in some cases, single parents. It’s a once-in-a-lifetime experience for many of them, and it’s a privilege for me to be the guiding person in that situation.” 
“Nuestros estudiantes aprenderán sobre otra cultura al estar allí y experimentarla”, dijo. “La gente de Todos Santos estuvo dispuesta a darnos su tiempo, su energía, su información. Muchos de nuestros estudiantes son de primera generación, bilingües y, en algunos casos, padres solteros. Es una experiencia única en la vida para muchos de ellos, y es un privilegio para mí ser la persona que los guíe en esa situación”.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Investigating a mysterious plant | Investigación de una planta misteriosa 
Until fairly recently, Dr. Sang-Hyuck Park had never seen cannabis, never smelled it and certainly had not used it. So, you might wonder how Park came to CSU Pueblo’s groundbreaking Institute of Cannabis Research.  
“When I first heard about the _Cannabis sativa_ L., also known as marijuana, I noticed that there were significant knowledge gaps about this long-time illegal plant.” he said. “For me, as a plant molecular biologist, the Institute provided a great opportunity for me to investigate the mysterious plant: I could be a pioneer in this area.”  
Hasta hace poco, el Dr. Sang-Hyuck Park nunca había visto el cannabis, nunca lo había olido y ciertamente no lo había usado. Entonces, quizás se pregunte cómo llegó Park al innovador Instituto de Investigación de Cannabis de CSU Pueblo. 
“Cuando escuché por primera vez sobre el Cannabis sativa L., también conocida como marihuana, noté que faltaban importantes conocimientos sobre esta planta ilegal desde hacía mucho tiempo”, dijo. “Para mí, como biólogo molecular de plantas, el Instituto me brindó una gran oportunidad para investigar la misteriosa planta: podría ser un pionero en esta área”. 
 After joining the ICR, Park quickly learned about the enormous potential of cannabis as a medicinal agent and its numerous applications in both the medical and industrial field. He has worked with various farmers in Colorado interested in producing hemp despite having no idea how to grow it. Park's research and knowledge gained during years of working with the U.S. Department of Agriculture on cotton and other agriculturally important crops helped him establish best practices in cannabis cultivation.  
Después de unirse al ICR, Park aprendió rápidamente sobre el enorme potencial del cannabis como agente medicinal y sus numerosas aplicaciones tanto en el campo médico como industrial. Ha trabajado con varios agricultores en Colorado interesados en producir cáñamo a pesar de no tener idea de cómo cultivarlo. La investigación y el conocimiento de Park adquiridos durante los años de trabajo con el Departamento de Agricultura de los EE. UU. sobre el algodón y otros cultivos importantes para la agricultura lo ayudaron a establecer las mejores prácticas en el cultivo de cannabis. 
  
News about the Institute’s work has spread across the globe, and Park is currently collaborating with international partners, answering questions about how to cultivate and best utilize cannabis and its natural products such as fibers, seeds and cannabinoids. Most of his work has come in his native South Korea, where cannabis is still illegal but an intriguing product for both farmers and medical researchers.   
Park said misconceptions about cannabis are slowly evolving into genuine interest in the plant’s enormous potential for good on numerous fronts.  
 Las noticias sobre el trabajo del Instituto se han extendido por todo el mundo, y Park colabora actualmente con socios internacionales, respondiendo a preguntas sobre cómo cultivar y utilizar mejor el cannabis y sus productos naturales, como las fibras, semillas y los cannabinoides. La mayor parte de su trabajo se ha producido en su país natal, Corea del Sur, donde el cannabis sigue siendo ilegal, pero es un producto intrigante tanto para los agricultores como para los investigadores médicos. 
Park dijo que los conceptos erróneos sobre el cannabis están evolucionando lentamente hacia un interés genuino en el enorme potencial de la planta para el bien en numerosas áreas. 
 
“Although there are still many unknowns, we have already witnessed that cannabis can be beneficial to patients suffering from various illnesses,” Park said. “A few drops of CBD oil administered sublingually can save the life of someone experiencing an epileptic seizure, and there is also evidence that it may help to alleviate symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients. This plant is truly a gift from the gods. However, there is still much research needed to better understand the mechanisms by which cannabinoids interact with our bodies, as well as to investigate any potential dependencies and side effects.” 
“Aunque todavía hay muchas incógnitas, ya hemos sido testigos de que el cannabis puede ser beneficioso para los pacientes que padecen diversas enfermedades”, dijo Park. “Unas pocas gotas de aceite de CBD administradas por vía sublingual pueden salvar la vida de alguien que sufre un ataque epiléptico, y también hay evidencia de que puede ayudar a aliviar los síntomas en pacientes con enfermedad de Parkinson. Esta planta es verdaderamente un regalo de los dioses. Sin embargo, todavía se necesita mucha investigación para comprender mejor los mecanismos por los cuales los cannabinoides interactúan con nuestros cuerpos, así como para investigar las posibles dependencias y efectos secundarios".

fields.Primary Story Content:
**Connecting with Kids | Conectarse con los niños**
Believing in the power of bilingual education | Creyendo en el poder de la educación bilingüe

Like many teenagers, Roni Capin Rivera-Ashford had a bit of a rebellious streak. 
Raised in a household where their culture was different from the majority of the population in the border town of Nogales, AZ, Roni had fallen in love with a boy outside her culture and faith, and her parents sent her to a boarding school in California, hoping the separation would end the relationship. 

Como muchos adolescentes, Roni Capin Rivera-Ashford tenía una vena un tanto rebelde. 
Criada en un hogar donde la cultura era diferente que la mayoría de la gente en la ciudad fronteriza de Nogales, Arizona, se había enamorado de un chico de otra  cultura y otra fe por lo cual sus padres la mandaron a un internado en California, con la esperanza de que la separación terminara la relación. 
 


“I was very angry, very lonely and very frustrated,” she said. “To get by, rather than participating in drinking alcohol and doing drugs, I would write. I would wake with night terrors at 2 a.m. and just write. For me, writing was a remedy.” 
Her first book, My Nana’s Remedies, paid homage to her grandmother and her bilingual upbringing. That’s also when Roni knew she needed to share her love for bilingual education through teaching. 

"Estaba muy enojada, muy sola y muy frustrada", nos contó. “Para sobrevivir, en vez de beber alcohol y consumir drogas, se ponía a escribir. Despertaba con terrores nocturnos a las 2 a.m. y simplemente se ponía a escribir. El escribir fue un remedio para mí”. 
Su primer libro, Los remedios de mi nana, rindió homenaje a su abuela y a su crianza bilingüe. Fue entonces también cuando supo que necesitaba compartir su amor por la educación bilingüe a través de sus esfuerzos como maestra. 


Eventually she joined her boyfriend (and future husband) at CSU Pueblo and they both studied toward teaching careers. Rivera-Ashford graduated in three years with distinction and moved back to Nogales to teach in a place where she knew her skills were urgently needed.   
“My first year was very challenging but I was very well prepared by my time at CSU Pueblo,” she said. “I was teaching Spanish speakers how to read in English, and I quickly discovered there was very little age-appropriate material for teaching young students. That’s when I started utilizing My Nana’s Remedies as a teaching tool.” 

Con el tiempo, se reunió con su novio (y futuro esposo) en CSU Pueblo y ambos estudiaron en carreras de educación. Rivera-Ashford se graduó con distinción en tres años y regresó a Nogales para enseñar en un lugar donde sabía que sus habilidades eran extremadamente útiles.  
“Mi primer año me presentó con muchos retos, pero llegué bien preparada de CSU Pueblo”, dijo. “Estaba enseñando a hispanoparlantes a leer en inglés y pronto me di cuenta que había muy poco material apropiado para niños de esta edad. Fue entonces cuando empecé a utilizar Los remedios de mi nana como instrumento de enseñanza”. 


After teaching for several years, Rivera-Ashford became a translator, converting English books to Spanish to create more access for young readers. This new job gave her time to pursue her writing passion, and she has produced several books. 
Disney heard about her skill as a bilingual writer and contracted her to write a book adaptation of the Oscar-winning film Coco. She has worked on several book projects for Disney’s Coco since then. 
“It was a wonderful experience and a very exciting time for me,” she said of her work on the Coco books. “It did a lot for my career to have my name connected to Disney.” 

Después de enseñar durante varios años, Rivera-Ashford se convirtió en traductora y traducía libros del inglés al español para crear más acceso para los lectores jóvenes. Este nuevo trabajo le dio tiempo para dedicarse a su pasión por la escritura y ha producido varios libros. 
Disney se enteró de su habilidad como escritora bilingüe y la contrató para escribir un libro que fuera una adaptación de la película ganadora del Oscar Coco. Desde entonces, ha trabajado en varios proyectos de libros para acompañar a la película Coco de Disney/Pixar. 
"Fue una experiencia maravillosa y un momento muy emocionante para mí", dijo sobre su trabajo en los libros para Coco. “Tener mi nombre conectado con Disney ha contribuido mucho a mi carrera”. 
She says her published works are like her children in that there are no favorites, yet she loves them equally for different reasons, for the unique qualities of each. Roni's most recent project is her first YA chapter book, about an extraordinary individual who was born in Cananea, Sonora, Mexico, immigrated to the U.S. when he was two years old, and faced much poverty and discrimination. Through perseverance and public education Raúl H. Castro overcame his life's challenges. He went on to become a boxing champion, teacher, lawyer, judge, three times U.S. Ambassador and Arizona’s first Latino governor. She calls her award-winning book Raulito: The First Latino Governor of Arizona. 

Ella dice que sus obras publicadas son como sus hijos en el sentido de que no hay favoritos, el tanto de amor es igual por diferentes razones, por las cualidades únicas de cada uno. El proyecto más reciente de Roni es su primer libro de capítulos para jóvenes, sobre un individuo extraordinario que nació en Cananea, Sonora, México, emigró a los EE. UU. cuando tenía dos años y enfrentó mucha pobreza y discriminación. A través de la perseverancia y la educación pública Raúl H. Castro superó los desafíos de su vida. Luego se convirtió en campeón de boxeo, maestro, abogado, juez, tres veces embajador de Estados Unidos y el primer gobernador latino de Arizona. Ella nombra a su premiado libro Raulito: El primer gobernador latino de Arizona. 
> _“I was fortunate to meet Governor Castro and visit him monthly for meals and interviews to record his story. It was such an inspiration that I just had to write a book,” she said. “The poverty he experienced, the discrimination – he overcame all of that with education and simply caring for people. What an honor to tell his story!” _
> _“Tuve la suerte de conocer y visitar al Gobernador Castro. Cada mes compartimos comidas y entrevistas, anotando su historia tan inspiradora que tuve que escribir un libro”. “Él superó la pobreza y la discriminación que sufrió por medio de la educación y abogando por la gente. Ha sido un honor contar su historia”. _

**For Future Research | Para futuras investigaciones**
Learn all you can. Share what you learn. | Aprende todo lo que puedas. Comparte lo que aprendes.
[ Book on Arizona's first Latino governor chosen for National Book Fest ](https://www.kgun9.com/news/local-news/book-on-arizonas-first-latino-governor-gets-national-recognition-this-weekend)

fields.Primary Story Content:
Front Line Reporting| Informes de primera línea 
**CSU grad Charlie D’Agata risks his life to tell stories of war | El graduado de CSU Charlie D'Agata arriesga su vida para contar historias de guerra** 
Some might say Charlie D’Agata has one of the most exciting – and exhilarating – jobs in American journalism. 
After all, the Colorado State University graduate has been reporting from the most newsworthy but dangerous places in the world for the past two-plus decades for CBS News. He’s currently the lead reporter for CBS in Ukraine, chronicling the Russian invasion and Ukraine’s dogged defense of its homeland. 
Se podría decir que Charile D’Agata tiene uno de los trabajos más estimulantes del periodismo estadounidense. 
Después de todo, el graduado de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado ha estado haciendo reportajes desde los lugares más interesantes pero peligrosos del mundo durante las últimas dos décadas para CBS News. Actualmente es el reportero principal de CBS en Ucrania, y narra la invasión rusa y la tenaz defensa de Ucrania de su patria. 
“I don’t think anyone in their right mind should want to be a war correspondent,” D’Agata said during a recent stint from his home office in London. “For me, I always wanted to travel the world and be the next Hemingway, telling important stories. But it hasn’t been the easiest life. I didn’t get to see much of my kids growing up, and the work is incredibly dangerous.” 
“No creo que nadie en su sano juicio quiera ser corresponsal de guerra”, dijo D’Agata durante un período reciente desde su oficina central en Londres. “Para mí, siempre quise viajar por el mundo y ser el próximo Hemingway, contando historias importantes. Pero no ha sido la vida más fácil. No pude ver mucho del crecimiento de mis hijos, y el trabajo es increíblemente peligroso”. 
_D’Agata has experienced more than his share of close calls. During the Iraq War he and his colleagues inadvertently drove into an ambush, surviving mortar and other weapons fire. On another occasion, he and his crew stopped for ice cream in what they believed was a safe area. A car bomb went off two blocks away._ 
_“It can be absolutely terrifying,” he said._ 
D'Agata ha experimentado más que su parte de escaparse por los pelos. Durante la Guerra de Irak, él y sus colegas se dirigieron sin darse cuenta a una emboscada, sobreviviendo al fuego de morteros y otras armas. En otra ocasión, él y su equipo se detuvieron a tomar un helado en lo que creían que era un área segura. Un coche-bomba estalló a dos cuadras de distancia. 
“Puede ser absolutamente aterrador”, dijo. 
Ukraine, he said, can be especially dangerous. 
“The worst part about covering the Ukraine war is there’s no stand-off area – you’re always in range,” he said. “You can be wearing a helmet and a flak jacket and be in an armored car, but it doesn’t matter what you have protecting you. You don’t get a pass because you’re a journalist.” 
Ucrania, dijo, puede ser especialmente peligrosa. 
“La peor parte de cubrir la guerra de Ucrania es que no hay un área de separación, siempre estás dentro del alcance”, dijo. “Puedes llevar un casco y un chaleco antibalas y estar en un vehículo blindado, pero no importa lo que tengas protegiéndote. No obtienes un pase porque eres periodista”. 
Through it all he relies on the lessons he learned studying journalism at CSU. D’Agata came to CSU thinking he wanted to be a veterinarian, but once he got a taste of journalistic storytelling – particularly utilizing video – he was hooked. He and a couple of buddies even helped launch CTV – the award-winning campus television network – before he graduated in 1990 with a B.A. in journalism. 
“I have to dispel a myth: no one is a war correspondent for the thrill of it,” he said. “Anyone who has witnessed the horrors of war will tell you that, but you do feel like you’re doing important work – you get the privilege of witnessing history and sharing those stories. 
A pesar de todo, confía en las lecciones que aprendió al estudiar periodismo en CSU. D'Agata llegó a CSU pensando que quería ser veterinario, pero una vez que probó la narración periodística, particularmente utilizando videos, quedó enganchado. Él y un par de amigos incluso ayudaron a lanzar CTV, la galardonada cadena de televisión del campus, antes de graduarse en 1990 con un B.A. en periodismo. 
“Tengo que disipar un mito: nadie es corresponsal de guerra por la emoción de hacerlo”, dijo. “Cualquiera que haya sido testigo de los horrores de la guerra te lo dirá, pero sientes que estás haciendo un trabajo importante: tienes el privilegio de presenciar la historia y compartir esas historias”. 
“We try to get as close as we can to tell the story and have those impacted tell the story. Those are the fundamentals I learned at Colorado State, and I’ll always be grateful for that.” 
“Tratamos de acercarnos lo más posible para contar la historia y hacer que los afectados cuenten la historia. Esos son los fundamentos que aprendí en Colorado State, y siempre estaré agradecido por eso”. 
Resources  
<https://alumline.source.colostate.edu/reporting-on-war-and-disaster/>

fields.Primary Story Content:
In addition to serving as an instructor for CSU Global's Healthcare Administration and Management program, Dr. Phillip Finley serves as a Senior Public Health Advisor (PHA) for the Division of HIV Prevention within the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). He has been with the CDC for over 30 years and provides international support for the division's HIV prevention efforts. For example, Prep-funded research activities in Thailand and Kenya.

Dr. Finley has been involved in global health issues for over 15 years. Beginning in 2006, he was assigned to the Center for Global Health (CGH), working on numerous international projects. He has served as Deputy Director at Large for CDC Ghana and supported numerous activities within the Overseas Effectiveness Workforce Development group addressing the personnel needs of Locally Employed Staff at CDC/PEPFAR funded countries (_Barbados, Malawi, Mali, Ghana, Cameroon, South Africa, Botswana, India, Thailand, Kenya_, and internal CDC programs at HQ).

For the past two years, Dr. Finley has worked closely with the international CDC US Direct Hires in the countries of Kenya and Thailand, and he is returning in April 2023 for a site visit to assess their ongoing HIV research work. 

The CDC Thailand, Division of HIV Prevention (DHP) and Research work has been ongoing for several decades. Since joining his current team and branch in DHP, they have been in the process of helping transition their work from DHP Research over to the Center for Global Health (CGH) for more international work to be defined within the next few years. Dr. Finley's work focuses on helping in that transition to ensure their Locally Employed Staff receive the attention deserved. The research involves examining the importance of addressing lost to follow up barriers in HIV, as well as types of preventive treatments such as Prep and PEP that is used by many in the MSM Community (Men that have sex with men). The study of these two treatments will also provide the community with information on access and its effectiveness and usage.

The study and research findings that have not been completed will illustrate that community public health practice through hospitals and clinics, with assistance from the Ministry of Health (MoH), will inform the community on best practices. This visit will also give a moment of appreciation and applause to the work of their Locally Employed Staff, who keep their laboratory and research programs moving forward through their collaborative work.

Dr. Finley also helps support HIV research work being conducted in Kenya by ensuring all financial allocations are distributed and spent in support of laboratory science. Dr. Finley uses the information garnered through his international work to share real-world scenarios with his students to the benefit of their learning.
fields.es-StoryTitle: Ayuda para la prevención del VIH
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: A gold and black image of pills spelling out "HIV"
fields.Impactful Quote: "As a CDC Senior Public Health Advisor (PHA) for the past 34 years, what’s most important as an adjunct instructor is sharing my knowledge and expertise in domestic and international work. What has stood out to me most as an adjunct is the importance of 'Global Health' and 'Health Policy' courses. Each one of these courses embraces the need to discuss global health epidemics and pandemics. I have recognized that students have similar concerns in terms of global health and relationship building among ministries of health, state health offices, and public vs. private health care facilities, as well as COVID-19 mitigation success, compliance, and policy assessments," said Dr. Finley.

fields.Primary Story Content:
The devastating events in March 2011 at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan following a major earthquake resulted in the need for a process to treat radioactive liquid waste.

At the time, CSU Global faculty member Dr. John Sinclair's company was working on an advanced liquid waste processing system to support TEPCO at the Fukushima site. Dr. Sinclair was working in a hybrid project management and development role with the project and frequently traveled to Japan in this capacity. Dr. Sinclair's company took on tasks to help with the management of radioactive materials and the development of long-term decommissioning plans. Dr. Sinclair was also involved with offering advice regarding the management of contaminated waters, removal of fuel from damaged reactors, as well as the design of radiation monitoring systems. In January 2020, systems in place from Dr. Sinclair's company were celebrated at Fukushima Daiichi as a significant milestone in safely treating more than 1 million cubic meters of radioactive liquid effluent, helping Dr. Sinclair's international partners get closer to their goals.

This project experience exemplified the vision of CSU Global, showing that education can reach around the globe and lead to real-world solutions and a stronger global community. Dr. Sinclair was able to bridge language and cultural barriers and use project management, marketing, and international business concepts to help global partners. This experience carries back to the classroom where students can interact with instructors like Dr. Sinclair who not only have academic credentials, but also global experience applying ethical business solutions.
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan
fields.Impactful Quote: “It was an honor to work with Japan, TEPCO, and other international stakeholders for this very important mission. The containers that our team provided were essential for the clean-up and containment of radioactive waste at Fukushima," said Dr. Sinclair.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Daniel Bowan never met an adventure he didn’t like. 
Daniel Bowan nunca conoció una aventura que no le gustara. 
From rock climbing to telemark skiing to whitewater rafting to mountain biking to playing or coaching lacrosse, he’s always ready to challenge himself and learn something new. 
“I always want to step outside my comfort zone,” he said. “I want to live without regrets, to see the world. Testing ourselves and our limits are crucial to really growing as a person.” 
Desde la escalada en roca hasta el esquí de telemark, el rafting en aguas bravas, el ciclismo de montaña y jugar o entrenar lacrosse, siempre está listo para desafiarse a sí mismo y aprender algo nuevo. 
“Siempre quiero salir de mi zona de confort”, dijo. “Quiero vivir sin remordimientos, ver el mundo. Ponernos a prueba a nosotros mismos y nuestros límites es crucial para realmente crecer como persona”. 
Bowan, who teaches ecotourism, recreation and outdoor leadership, is one of the most popular professors at CSU Pueblo. He encourages his students to stretch themselves, try new things and learn about new cultures. That’s why he was so excited to offer students a chance to learn and grow at CSU’s Todos Santos Center in Baja California Sur Mexico. 
“I love that our students have the chance to go to Todos Santos,” he said. “It’s a place to grow and become global citizens. We’ve got up to eight courses available to students from both CSU campuses, and the impact is amazing. It really helps immerse students in the culture, and it helps them grow in ways they never imagined. We’ve got kids who have never seen the ocean who end up swimming with whale sharks. It really is an amazing experience.” 
Bowan, quien enseña ecoturismo, recreación y liderazgo al aire libre, es uno de los profesores más populares en CSU Pueblo. Alienta a sus alumnos a esforzarse, probar cosas nuevas y aprender sobre nuevas culturas. Por eso estaba tan emocionado de ofrecer a los estudiantes la oportunidad de aprender y crecer en el Centro Todos Santos de CSU en Baja California Sur, México. 
“Me encanta que nuestros estudiantes tengan la oportunidad de ir a Todos Santos”, dijo. “Es un lugar para crecer y convertirse en ciudadanos globales. Tenemos hasta ocho cursos disponibles para estudiantes de ambos campus de la CSU y el impacto es increíble. Realmente ayuda a sumergir a los estudiantes en la cultura y los ayuda a crecer de maneras que nunca imaginaron. Tenemos niños que nunca han visto el océano y terminan nadando con tiburones ballena. Realmente es una experiencia increíble”. 
In addition to exposing CSU Pueblo students to their first international travel, Bowan has worked with university officials from nearby La Paz to provide Mexican students the opportunity to come to Colorado and explore our culture. These high-impact practices have become transformational for many students, pushing them to expand their international education experiences. 
Además de exponer a los estudiantes de CSU Pueblo a su primer viaje internacional, Bowan ha trabajado con funcionarios universitarios de la cercana La Paz para brindarles a los estudiantes mexicanos la oportunidad de venir a Colorado y explorar nuestra cultura. Estas prácticas de alto impacto se han vuelto transformadoras para muchos estudiantes, empujándolos a expandir sus experiencias de educación internacional. 
“To be able to offer this amazing resource in Todos Santos – it really is the chance of a lifetime for many of these students. It’s the ultimate field trip!” he said. “The more we can put our students into authentic places and offer real learning, the better they will be. They get this out-of-body experience, they enter this zone. We create challenges, and the result is some really special experiences. That’s what education is all about.” 
“Poder ofrecer este increíble recurso en Todos Santos, realmente es la oportunidad de su vida para muchos de estos estudiantes. ¡Es la mejor excursión!” él dijo. “Cuanto más podamos poner a nuestros estudiantes en lugares auténticos y ofrecer un aprendizaje real, mejor serán. Obtienen esta experiencia fuera del cuerpo, entran en esta zona. Creamos desafíos y el resultado son experiencias realmente especiales. De eso se trata la educación”.
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: A street in Todos Santos, Mexico with colorful buildings and colorful flags hanging across the street.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Dr. Eva Fisher’s goal since recovering from body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) has been to become an advocate for awareness and provide hope for others that recovery is possible. As a member of the International OCD Foundation BDD Special Interest Group, she shared her personal story on the Foundation’s website, focused on the self-diagnosis that led her to seek professional help, and has authored multiple articles about coping with and recovery from BDD. Now, years later, she leads others down the path from constant mental pain to peace with one’s appearance.

Dr. Fisher learned about the International OCD Foundation and their efforts to provide support to individuals with OCD and related disorders while conducting research for her PhD dissertation. At her first Annual OCD Conference and BDD Special Interest Group (SIG) meeting, she met Katharine Phillips and Sabine Wilhelm, whose  research on BDD enabled her to diagnose herself with BDD after having had the disorder for more than 20 years. She learned during her research that individuals who suffer from BDD often feel alone and unable to share their feelings with friends and loved ones. That knowledge led her to focus her dissertation research on the personal disclosure and social support shared on an online forum for individuals with BDD symptoms.

Now, Dr. Fisher facilitates support groups for adults with BDD. She started the Recovery from BDD Facebook support group, where she posts blogs about how to cope with symptoms of the disorder. In addition, Dr. Fisher authored a book based on her dissertation research: The BDD Family: Coping with Body Dysmorphic Disorder in a Peer Support Group.

Dr. Fisher received her PhD from Colorado State University and currently serves an instructor at Colorado State University Global.
fields.Spatial Angle: Internationally through the online support group. Spatial Angle = Boston, Mass.

fields.Impactful Quote: "My work as an advocate and support group facilitator is empowering and rewarding. I feel that everyone whom I have met, including the BDD researchers, clinicians, and support group members, are all part of a global BDD family. We are all dedicated to helping those with body dysmorphic disorder get the support and treatment they need to recover," said Dr. Eva Fisher.

fields.Primary Story Content:
# **Using Her Mom Voice | Alzar su voz de mamá**
CSUP grad fighting for a better future for her daughter and the planet | Una graduada de CSUP lucha por un futuro mejor para su hija y el pl
**Jordan Mecham**

Jordan Mecham had grown weary of hearing about climate change and the impact it was having on her and her young daughter in Pueblo – not to mention the entire planet. But she wasn’t quite sure what to do. 
That’s when the value of her degree in sociology from CSU Pueblo and the teachers who inspired her kicked in. She had helped do research on a project, led by assistant professor Heidi Reynolds-Stenson, that focused on the Black Lives Matter movement, and she realized that she had found her passion. 
“I want a livable climate and socially just world for my daughter, and I can only achieve that by standing up for myself and using my voice,” Mecham said. 

Jordan Mecham se había cansado de escuchar sobre el cambio climático y el impacto que estaba teniendo en ella y su pequeña hija en Pueblo, sin mencionar el planeta entero. Pero ella no estaba muy segura de qué hacer. 
Fue entonces cuando se hizo evidente el valor de su título en sociología de CSU Pueblo y de los profesores que la inspiraron. Había ayudado a realizar una investigación en un proyecto, dirigido por la Dra. Heidi Reynolds-Stenson, que se centraba en el movimiento Black Lives Matter, y se dio cuenta de que había encontrado su pasión. 
“Quiero un clima habitable y un mundo socialmente justo para mi hija, y sólo puedo lograrlo defendiéndome y usando mi voz”, dijo Mecham. 
 


She started doing volunteer work for Mothers Out Front, a national organization that empowers women – especially mothers and grandmothers – to band together to fight climate change. The organization has taken on major polluters to clean up air and water and pushed for green energy solutions to everyday problems. 

Comenzó a trabajar como voluntaria para Mothers Out Front, una organización nacional que empodera a las mujeres, especialmente a las madres y abuelas, para que se unan para luchar contra el cambio climático. La organización se ha enfrentado a los principales contaminadores para limpiar el aire y el agua y ha impulsado soluciones de energía verde para los problemas cotidianos. 


In Pueblo, a coal-fired power plant that provides energy for the Denver-metro area while polluting the air in Pueblo is a major concern for locals. In the past, it was left to the power plant to monitor air pollution and issue advisories, but Mothers Out Front worked for a better solution. 
“We applied for a grant that helped us purchase 20 air monitors to be installed throughout the city,” Mecham said. “Now, we can provide accurate data that shows where people are being impacted the most by pollution. The community deserves to have this data.” 
Mecham, who grew up in a small mining town in Nevada, has worked on other Mothers Up Front projects in Pueblo, removing trash from various sites around the city and advocating for clean water. 

En Pueblo, una planta de energía alimentada con carbón que proporciona energía al área metropolitana de Denver y al mismo tiempo contamina el aire en Pueblo es una gran preocupación para los habitantes. En el pasado, correspondía a la planta de energía monitorear la contaminación del aire y emitir avisos, pero Mothers Out Front trabajó para encontrar una mejor solución. 
“Solicitamos una subvención que nos ayudó a comprar 20 monitores de aire para instalarlos en toda la ciudad”, dijo Mecham. “Ahora podemos proporcionar datos precisos que muestren dónde las personas se ven más afectadas por la contaminación. La comunidad merece tener estos datos”. 
Mecham, que creció en un pequeño pueblo minero de Nevada, ha trabajado en otros proyectos de Mothers Out Front en Pueblo, sacando basura de varios sitios de la ciudad y abogando por el agua potable. 

> _“Climate change is impacting the earth, and we need to keep our air, water and land clean for generations to come,” she said. “The community needs more passion and more people who are invested in making the community a better place. My daughter is my reason for fighting for our planet. I want her and all women, mothers and grandmothers to have radical hope for our future.” _
> Jordan Mecham
> _"El cambio climático está afectando a la Tierra y debemos mantener limpios el aire, el agua y la tierra para las generaciones venideras", afirmó. “La comunidad necesita más pasión y más personas comprometidas en hacer de la comunidad un lugar mejor. Mi hija es mi razón de luchar por nuestro planeta. Quiero que ella y todas las mujeres, madres y abuelas tengan una esperanza radical en nuestro futuro”. _
> _Jordan Mecham_

fields.Primary Story Content:
# **Creating the Peace Corps | creando el Cuerpo de Paz**
Maurice Albertson’s impact is being felt around the world | El impacto de Maurice Albertson se siente en todo el mundo
**Maurice Albertson**

Few people have made a more significant impact on our world than Maurice Albertson. 
Albertson, a professor of civil engineering at Colorado State University from 1947-98, was one of the most important figures in the university’s history. Not only did his relentless pursuit of excellence help create the CSU Research Foundation, but his overseas work also took CSU’s land-grant mission global for the first time, establishing the university’s reputation as a research giant.

Pocas personas han tenido un impacto más significativo en nuestro mundo que Maurice Albertson. 
Albertson, profesor de ingeniería civil en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado de 1947 a 1998, fue una de las figuras más importantes en la historia de la universidad. Su incansable búsqueda de la excelencia no solo ayudó a crear la Fundación de Investigación de CSU, sino que su trabajo en el extranjero también hizo que la misión de concesión de tierras de CSU fuera global por primera vez, estableciendo la reputación de la universidad como un gigante de la investigación. 
Still, it was his partnership with the Kennedy Administration in the early 1960s that made Albertson a legendary figure. Teaming with Pauline Birky-Kreutzer, a research associate at CSU he had worked with overseas, the blueprint that became the Peace Corps was created and presented to Sargent Shriver, the first director of the Peace Corps.  

Aun así, fue su asociación con la Administración Kennedy a principios de la década de 1960 lo que convirtió a Albertson en una figura legendaria. En equipo con Pauline Birky-Kreutzer, una investigadora asociada de CSU con la que había trabajado en el extranjero, se creó el plan que se convirtió en el Cuerpo de Paz y se le presentó a Sargent Shriver, el primer director del Cuerpo de Paz. 



Within a year, 400 Peace Corps volunteers were working in the field. Since then, nearly a quarter of a million volunteers have worked in more than 140 countries on six continents, working to improve the lives of the less fortunate. 
CSU has been home to hundreds of Peace Corps volunteers, ranking in the top 10 all-time among U.S. universities. 

Dentro de un año, 400 voluntarios del Cuerpo de Paz estaban trabajando en el campo. Desde entonces, casi un cuarto de millón de voluntarios ha trabajado en más de 140 países en seis continentes, trabajando para mejorar la vida de los menos afortunados. 
CSU ha sido el hogar de cientos de voluntarios del Cuerpo de Paz, clasificándose entre las 10 mejores de todos los tiempos entre las universidades de EE. UU. 
 


Albertson, who died in 2009 at age 90, was awarded the Founders Day Medal, which honors CSU’s most important figures, by then- CSU President Frank in 2011. 
“Professor Albertson will be remembered as one of the truly great figures in the history of Colorado State University,” said Frank, now Chancellor of the CSU System. “It was primarily because of his work as a professor that CSU attracted and graduated its first doctoral student and assumed its full role and responsibility as a research university. He was an innovative teacher and scholar who dedicated his life to improving the living conditions of people around the world and who helped create, through the Peace Corps, a vehicle through which generations of young people have channeled their compassion and commitment into useful and important work for developing communities. CSU is grateful and honored to have been Professor Albertson’s academic home.” 
Albertson worked until his final days on various projects around the world, leaving a legacy few can match. His selfless approach to life continues to make an impact. 

Albertson, quien murió en 2009 a los 90 años, recibió la Medalla del Día de los Fundadores, que honra a las figuras más importantes de CSU, de manos del entonces presidente de CSU, Frank, en 2011.
“El profesor Albertson será recordado como una de las figuras verdaderamente grandes en la historia de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado”, dijo Frank, ahora rector del Sistema CSU. “Fue principalmente debido a su trabajo como profesor que CSU atrajo y graduó a su primer estudiante de doctorado y asumió su rol y responsabilidad completos como universidad de investigación. Fue un maestro y académico innovador que dedicó su vida a mejorar las condiciones de vida de las personas en todo el mundo y ayudó a crear, a través del Cuerpo de Paz, un vehículo a través del cual generaciones de jóvenes han canalizado su compasión y compromiso hacia un trabajo útil e importante para las comunidades en desarrollo. CSU está agradecida y honrada de haber sido el hogar académico del profesor Albertson”. 
Albertson trabajó hasta sus últimos días en varios proyectos alrededor del mundo, dejando un legado que pocos pueden igualar. Su enfoque en el bienestar de otros continúa teniendo un impacto. 
  

> _“After almost 88 years of thinking about it, I’ve come to the conclusion that we’re on earth for one purpose and one purpose only, and that’s to help people that are less fortunate,” Albertson said in a 2007 interview. _
> _“Después de casi 88 años de pensar en ello, llegué a la conclusión de que estamos en la tierra con un solo propósito, y es ayudar a las personas menos afortunadas”, dijo Albertson en una entrevista de 2007. _
fields.Spatial Angle: Most popular location for Peace Corps volunteers is Zambia, but volunteers are around the world.
